intro.text: Before choosing to install Linux, you must choose which distribution of Linux you would like to install. To help you find what distribution is right for you, here are some details on some of the most popular distributions of Linux.

sections.text: Ubuntu is one of if not the most popular distribution of Linux out there. Ubuntu is a user friendly operating system that is also free to install and use. The operating system also allows users to boot the system from a USB so there's no real commitment in using Ubuntu if you don’t want to overwrite your computer's native operating system. One reason to choose Ubuntu as your Linux distribution of choice as compared to other distributions is that Ubuntu is made to be user friendly and is a great starting place for people interested in Linux. After all one of Ubuntu’s slogans is Linux for Humans.

Debian is an older linux distribution that other operating systems like Ubuntu are based off of. Like Ubuntu Debian is free but doesn’t update as often as  other Linux distributions. This can actually be a good thing as it makes the operating system more stable which is very needed for some systems.

Like other distributions Fedora is free to install but is considered to be bleeding edge which means it always contains the newest versions of software. Different from Ubuntu, Fedora doesn’t make its own desktop environment nor does it make its own software. Instead Fedora uses upstream software and provides a platform for it.

Linux Mint is a distribution of Linux that was built on top of Ubuntu. Initially Mint was was used due to its inclusion of media codecs and proprietary software Ubuntu didn’t have. Now Mint is its own distribution and doesn’t have Ubuntu’s unity desktop and instead has its own called Cinnamon. Updates for Linux Mint are also more relaxed when compared to other distributions.

sections.header: OK, so which one is better?
sections.text: Figuring out which Linux is best for you can be tough but hopefully a few suggestions should help. If you're looking for an easy to use, widely supported distribution then Ubuntu is a great choice. If you're looking for an older, more stable distribution then Debian is a good choice. If you want to take a look at and use the newest versions of software then Fedora might be what you’re looking for. Finally, if you’re looking for a less resource hungry distribution then you should take a look at Linux Mint.
